0.user_question: Bob and Alice each have a bag that contains one ball of each of the colors,  blue, green, orange, red, and violet. Alice randomly selects one ball from her bag and puts it into Bob's bag. Bob then randomly selects one ball from his bag and  puts it into Alice's bag. What is the probability that after this process the contents of the two bags are the same?

direct_answer.text: There are five different ways to swap balls without making the content equal -- exchanging none; swapping any other single pair besides Blue/Red ; Swapping Orange/Violet . Hence , outcomes when both get back original colours happen in six cases :no change Red & Green / no change Violet&Orange etc.. And thus Probability would be=$\dfrac {6} {C_{5}^{2}}=6/(5*4)=\dfrac {3} {10}=0.3 $. 0.user_question: Bob and Alice each have a bag that contains one ball of each of the colors,  blue, green, orange, red, and violet. Alice randomly selects one ball from her bag and puts it into Bob's bag. Bob then randomly selects one ball from his bag and  puts it into Alice's bag. What is the probability that after this process the contents of the two bags are the same?

1.subquestion: Before any balls were transferred, how many possible combinations could exist if every color must appear once per bag (i.e., no repeat)?

subanswer.text: Each person originally had five different colored balls; since they put them together without replacement, there were initially ${10}\choose{5}$=252 distinct ordered pairs which satisfy the requirement. The answer is 252.

subanswer.text: Each person originally had five different colored balls; since they put them together without replacement, there were initially ${10}\choose{5}$=252 distinct ordered pairs which satisfy the requirement. The answer is 252.

2.subquestion: After Alice transfers her selected ball into Bob’s collection but before he makes any selections himself, how many such possibilities remain among those who would not give him a duplicate set? In other words, consider only cases where at least one remaining unselected box differs across their collections than did either or both players prior to transferring anything over — leave aside scenarios involving multiple matches vs. pretransfer status quo conditions because our current focus concerns just single instances. Thus far about half seem likely based purely upon counting argumentation... However let me offer more insight here regarding relevant permutations/combinations within context provided thus far…

0.user_question: Bob and Alice each have a bag that contains one ball of each of the colors,  blue, green, orange, red, and violet. Alice randomly selects one ball from her bag and puts it into Bob's bag. Bob then randomly selects one ball from his bag and  puts it into Alice's bag. What is the probability that after this process the contents of the two bags are the same?

direct_answer.text: There are five different ways to swap balls without making the content equal -- exchanging none; swapping any other single pair besides Blue/Red ; Swapping Orange/Violet . Hence , outcomes when both get back original colours happen in six cases :no change Red & Green / no change Violet&Orange etc.. And thus Probability would be=$\dfrac {6} {C_{5}^{2}}=6/(5*4)=\dfrac {3} {10}=0.3 $. Already mentioned steps above were used as followings:-Step I :- No exchange --------> Original Condition Step II :- Exchange nonblueredpair [excluding bluered] --->> Remaining Cases Total possible combination count --> Five pairs combinations Count-->NochangeCount-->Bluegreencount-->Greenorange count-->Orangegreen count-->violetandornpairs-->(Two Pairs)->Total Combinations=(Case i)+(Case ii)+(caseiii)+(caseiv)+(Case vii)+(casesix)=OnePairExchangedBothColours===>OriginalConditionsoProbabilityforonepairexchange ==<P(/OnePairExchanged)/totalcombo!=probof
